original_title: Sri Lanka rupee at 296.50 /297.50 to dollar at open, bond yields up
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s rupee opened at 296.50 /297.50 against the US dollar in the spot market on Monday, while bond yields were up, dealers said.
The rupee closed at  296.00 /297.50 to the US dollar on Friday after opening around 302.80/303.10 rupees.
Sri Lanka’s rupee is appreciating amid negative private credit which has reduced outflows after the central bank hiked rates and stopped printing money.

In the first year of an International Monetary Fund program, a pegged central bank usually collects reserves and mops up liquidity generated from the purchases or there is a balance of payments surplus.
The central bank has avoided printing money as far as possible and newly created liquidity has generally disappeared into an overnight liquidity shortage, instead of creating more credit.
Third world central bank generally do not appreciate currencies based on real effective exchange rate considerations. However Sri Lanka’s REER as calculated by the central bank is below 100.
A bond maturing on 01.09.2027 was quoted at 26.50/70 percent up from Friday’s close at 26.30/65 percent . (Colombo/May29/2023)
